heading: the opposite of attraction
subheading: researchers at penn discover evidence of materials with opposite charges that repel each other instead of attract. they can build themselves into nifty contraptions, too. by kristen philipkoski
author: kristen philipkoski
text: opposite charges attract -- it's a concept any high-school physics student can grasp. but a new study shows evidence of opposites that repel. researchers at the university of pennsylvania have discovered a new class of materials that automatically build themselves into flat structures. the material, which contains particles with opposite charges that appear to repel instead of attract, has potential applications in products such as biosensors and drug carriers, and in gene therapies."the message is when you look through the microscope, the things you see are not the only things there. you see these really large bacteria, but there are lots of atom-sized things that can be doing sneaky things," said philip nelson, the lead researcher on the project.in a vacuum, nelson said, all opposite charged particles attract. but since the particles the penn group studied were floating in water, smaller, invisible ions -- charged atoms -- surround larger molecules and influence their charge."this ain't a vacuum, this is a sort of seething soup of things you can see and things you can't see. so these things look bizarre and inexplicable," nelson said. "these ions sort of reduce the size of some effects. we thought that was really entertaining.""that's when you need to do some math to tell you what the things you can't see are doing," nelson added. "that's the role of the physicist: to put together the picture of what's out there and obvious and the other stuff that's not obvious but you know it's there."one researcher compared the phenomenon to a waterbed."if you're sitting on a waterbed, and someone else sits down, you end up falling together. you're not necessarily attracted to each other, but you're interacting indirectly," said david grier, associate professor of physics at the university of chicago.grier's studies have found particles with the same charge that attract instead of repel.the mystery of how exactly the big molecules influence the structure of the sea of small ions is an increasingly debated controversy among physicists, according to grier.the potential practicality of the research lies in the structures produced in conjunction with these changing charges. rather than form a full sheet that wraps around a sphere, they self-assemble a little patch, cover part of a sphere, then make another patch. this allows the structures to cover a sphere seamlessly, and prevents the sheet from breaking."you can't take a bunch of bathroom tiles and cover a sphere without any embarrassing gaps. so those guys wouldn't be nice and perfect and crystalline if they covered the whole sphere at once," nelson said. "that self-limitation seems to be important for flat plates."
